Let me try and sum up the gist of what was going on, in a story that seemed to come from a brief thought of a Kung-Fu movie from the notes of Robert Rodríguezes ideas pad after too many Tequila's. There was this guy, Golden Lion, who was killed by a few other poorly named lions, and this Golden Lion's son was on a mission to avenge his father's death, by the time I walked out of the film there was a brief appearance from an overweight Russell Crowe and aging Lucy Lu, whose characters relevance to the story wasn't clear but I am guessing they were going to get mixed up with the Blacksmith and his girlfriend, who again didn't seem to have too much relevance to the 'revenge mission' taking place, apart from the Blacksmiths narrative, which was poorly written. And don't worry, if you are planning on watching this movie once reading this review (which is very unlikely) there will be no spoilers, as again, I don't know the ending or twists myself. But let's go back to what I do know, and that is that this movie is a very poor one. You can see where the writer and director, former rapper RZA, got his influences from; and that's very clearly Quentin Tarantino, whose name appears on the poster declaring that he presents this movie. Now let's get things straight, in no way am I comparing the two, as Tarantino is a film god in my eyes, and all geniuses are close to insanity apparently, and this is clear here, as he allowed his friend to release this movie, but also attribute his name to it. However, I can slightly see why, and let me explain this before I sound insane, Tarantino loves Robert Rodriguez, and the latter creates movies in the same mould as this one, so my theory is that Tarantino thought RZA was creating a Rodriquez, but it just didn't turn out that way. The tongue-in-cheek nature of a Rodriquez film, mixed with over-the-top violence and a fantastic score, with brilliant actors littered throughout, was all attempted by RZA, but failed at it miserably. I walked away from the film trying to find him a little creative in thinking that it was possibly done tongue-in-cheek, but I don't think he is a clever enough film maker to pull it off. The script felt like an 80's dubbed Korean movie, with one liners that would even stand out in a Nicolas Cage movie. The fight sequences were all about shocking its audience with great effects and extreme blood and gore, but it was laughable. The corny and cringe-filled romantic scenes were made even worse by 90's porn music. In turn it all reminded me of the children's programme Power Rangers for some reason, an overly violent version. It was just terrible, need I remind you that I get all this from just 20 minutes of viewing, I could have probably written a novel after the whole thing. Let me give the man a break and just say let's forget about this movie, and hope that RZA comes back with something better next time. That's as nice as I can be. 1 out of 10.

Great costumes, extraordinary hair styles for men, pretty sets, flying action and blood blood blood are the main attractions here. Here are the main problems with the movie: 1. Bad acting - nearly all the leading roles provide us with poor performances, including RZA himself.

2. Bad storyline/script - the story isn't terrible, although similar plots have been regurgitated countless times before. But the progression of events and the way the story is pieced together lets the production down badly.

3. Bad direction - Although there are some scenes and shots in the movie which have some fancy and praise-worthy cinematography and fx, other parts of the movie just seem very quickly shot, without care. More attention by the director would have improved things.

4. Don't care about characters - this goes back to the acting and script. At no point in the movie do you really feel true empathy for the characters. They seem like cardboard cutouts, not real people.

5. Average martial arts - while there are some impressive fight scenes, most of the martial arts in the movie is nothing spectacular.

Overall: This really comes across like an episode of the old Power Rangers TV Show, cheap and rushed. Or like the first Mortal Kombat movie. They all have a similar sort of vibe. If you removed the blood and gore from the movie you could see it as purely children's entertainment. As far as it's replay value, I'd say it's about zero. Can't say I'll ever watch it again.

However, if you're a fan of RZA and Wu Tang, you'll hear some of their tracks throughout the film and get to see RZA in the role of a protagonist. I don't think you'll be amazed by any means, but not totally disappointed. It gets 4 out of 10 from me, a lot of other kung fu flicks from the 70s and 80s, even up to present day, are much better than this. As long as you watch it without expecting anything great you'll possibly be mildly entertained. You'll want to watch it anyway if you're a Wu fan, just don't expect Fist of Legend, Drunken Master or Shogun Assassin, it's nowhere near that level but still not the worst martial arts movie out there. Just a shame that it leans more towards being a bad film than a good film.

The action - It was legit to say the least. The movie dished out plenty of action and plenty of good action at that.

The bad:

Movie title - Honestly, if you see the movie you will realize why the title does not fit.

Not enough RZA - As the main character I would have loved to see way more RZA kicking butt.

The plot - Was it the greatest? No, it was a little lacking but NOT that big of a drawback.

Overall I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. It sounded AMAZING, looked crisp, had some superb action and was consistent. As RZA's directorial you couldn't ask for much better from the Abbott of the Wu. It brings action, legit characters and RZA kicking butt, what more do you need?

I will definitely recommend this to my friends.

review_detailed_main:
It's not often you find a film with no redeeming qualities or so many inexplicable features. For Example: -A black person in feudal China -A man who for no reason can change his skin into bronze on a whim -The entire population of China speaking English with American accents, although sometimes they speak Chinese and then revert back to English just because they can. -That prosthetic arms can be made of iron and when forced onto an amputee's stumps function perfectly.This is again in feudal China. -Also that once iron prostheses have been cleaved to your stumps you become proficient in unarmed combat -The existence of nylon tights and stockings in feudal China -1980s glam rock hair styling in feudal China -Did I mention that the prostheses have magical powers (not explained at all) and can somehow summon tornado's or something?

There was no coherent plot, zero opportunity to relate to the characters, a cast of what might as well have been tree stumps for the level of acting they delivered and a tonne of nonsensical choreographed violence. I accept that this last is usual of a martial arts film but at the same time added little and wasted time. The films score, celebrated by critics apparently, was not impressive as far as I'm concerned. That it sometimes featured rap songs or sci-fi esque synthesiser tones, amongst the regular backing, was also distracting and nonsensical.

There were also a number of pieces of symbolism which were entirely forced upon the audience. For example the way two dead bodies fell to form a Yin & Yang sign. Again these added nothing to the film and in fact detracted from it in the fashion in which they were delivered to the screen. I have seen more cogent symbolism in episodes of Family Guy.

As much as I like to see scantily clad women this use of cheap tricks to gain attention was gratuitous. That the one of the films major settings was a whorehouse explains this but at the same time it was not done tastefully. The desperation with which the director, RZA, tries to attract attention is pitiful. Someone also needs to tell him that split screen and screen-wipes are great tools to use in a comic book child's cartoon but aren't needed in grown-up's films.

Russel Crowe's performance was perhaps the only one which calls for any merit. However why he sullied his career by appearing in this example of cinema bilge is beyond me. His character also adds very little, his only motivation being greed and the small size of his role not allowing him to rescue the film. RZA appearing in his own movie is an act of colossal narcissism. That he wrote the film doesn't confer upon him the ability to act. Something he proved throughout the film. He can't direct either considering the bile he released. On a different note, in my opinion RZA isn't a real name. It's an acronym. Whatever RZA is attempting to prove by calling himself RZA is irrelevant. I think it makes him look stupid.

I considered at some point during the film that this might be spoof of the entire martial arts genre yet the film takes itself far too seriously for that. The opening and closing credits make it appear as though RZA was attempting a grindhouse style but doesn't follow through to any other portion of the film. I only managed to finish this film because I was writing this very review during the second half.

Don't watch this film. It will be a waste of your time. RZA shouldn't be allowed to direct any more if this is the standard we can expect from him.

Most Martial Arts films that are created in the Shaw Brothers tradition will always ask viewers to suspend their disbelief, and ask viewers to become steeped in the mythos of a story that is most times only hinted at, in much the same way that readers of comics are asked to within the pages of any given title. If you can watch a film like the "Five Deadly Venoms" and overlook the fact that its never explained why the Poison Clan members became bad guys, or why the last student(who was taught all the styles, but never mastered one) needed to seek the help of one the members of the Poison Clan to beat the others, you can overlook some of the story structure "problems" in The Man With the Iron Fists. If you know the genre, you know that this film is solid, and true to form. 8 out of 10.

As far as cinematics go, the acting was sub-par. The action sequences were poorly choreographed almost to the point where you can envision stunt rigging hanging from the limbs of the combatants. There is nothing even remotely interesting about the plot, it's predictable and just plain bad. The movie feels choppy and well... the director is horrible, no other way to put it. Then again, RZA is essentially just another flavor flav. If you want an real martial arts action film, there are hundreds of them produced in HK/China every year, just go to the foreign films section of Netflix or Blockbuster. If you want Quentin, watch Grindhouse.

Whats more, the director, RZA is a racist and yes, he is of a minority ethnic persuasion. Chinese people are portrayed as Mongol savages throughout the movie. There is an African fellow working as a blacksmith in British colonial China. There also happens to be a lone British officer wandering about what is described as a "jungle village" and there happens to be (conveniently) a classy brothel in the center of it all, reminiscent of Hong Kong during this time period. This is culturally, geographically, and historically incorrect. RZA manages to warp 4 separate parts of the globe from potentially different time periods, into one village.

Oh whats more, the treatment of the African man's arm amputations is inaccurate to say the least. Cauterizing the wound like they do would lead to infection and certain death. 19th century medical knowledge was certainly better than what is depicted in the movie.

What's more? LUCY LIU CANT SPEAK MANDARIN WORTH SHIFT. She should seriously stick to English speaking roles.

All this is due to ignorance on the part of the person who wrote the script RZA, but then again, he has just about the same education level as Flavor Flav. What more can you expect.

Honestly, as a Chinese-American and educated person, I was thoroughly insulted by this film.

Poorly developed characters, made you not care (Check)

Nicely shot action scenes. (No....)

movie_name: The Man with the Iron Fists
review_detailed_main: The Man with the Iron Fists is nothing more than a regular Martial Arts film with famous actors and a Wu-Tang Clan soundtrack. Sure a movie directed by the RZA and presented by Quentin Tarantino sounds like it would be an awesome film but it simply falls short of expectations. It seemed like the RZA tried to combine the run of a brink Kung Fu movie with the Exploitation genre all while trying to pay homage to Kill Bill. The story didn't make much sense, the fight choreography was not very good and the special effects were cheap. Now when I say the special effects were cheap I mean that the blood looked totally fake and that many of the fighting moves were completely ridiculous, especially the final blow in the final fight. On the upside the acting was halfway decent, the weapons were creative and some of the characters were somewhat likeable. The story basically follows a Blacksmith, an Emissary, some prostitutes and various clans that constantly battle each other for reasons that aren't entirely clear. Fighting ensues, people die and you can probably figure out the rest. Overall, if you're expecting Tarantino quality you'll be sorely disappointed and if you're a fan of Martial Arts films you still won't be very impressed. I would only recommend this film to fans of the Martial Arts genre. Even then I recommend waiting for this one to come out on home video.

Russell Crowe looks way too out of shape to be doing a fight scene, but he at least can act. Occasionally the film starts to pick up steam, only to lose it by introducing another plot line or segueing to a lengthy flashback.

There are a few fun moments to be had, mostly courtesy of Lucy Liu and her brothel, and some of the weapons are interesting, but they overdo that also. The set designs are very good and the costuming is a standout. Other than that, there's just no reason to watch this film, unless you need to see every homage to kung fu movies ever made.

movie_name: The Man with the Iron Fists
review_title: Good enough movie, but some parts were bad...
review_detailed_main:
I had some reservations about this movie, but still gave it a go. And I will say that the movie was entertaining, but certain parts about it was really not in my taste or liking.

For starters, then having RZA in one of the lead roles, seriously? It was just one of those Things that didn't Work well with me. And also, I was wondering why the Chinese people were speaking English. It just didn't make any sense, but of course it appeals to people scared of foreign films and easier to keep it in English. And the movie did have too much of a Westernized touch to it. I guess that is what you get when non-Chinese attempt at making a Chinese action martial arts movie.

The martial arts and fighting sequences were quite good, but of course why wouldn't it be with Cory Yuen behind the choreography? And the entire scenery, sets and atmosphere was good. It is hard not to get taken in by the impressive work that went into the production of the movie and the details; ranging from the costumes to the buildings.

I will say that the characters were colorful and well-chiseled out. I enjoyed how much detail and story that went into each character. And they were nicely brought to life on the screen by the actors and actresses, but also by the costumes and props.

"The Man With the Iron Fists" has an impressive cast list, especially amongst the Asian cast. If you are familiar with Asian cinema, then you will find yourself in for a treat when you see who is in this movie.

The ultimately downside to this movie was the choice of music. Wow, are you kidding me? The music in the movie was bloody awful, and it was so out of tune with the entire movie. The music was so bad that I was wishing for an 'exclude the music score' button on the remote control.

But all in all, aside from some eye- and ear-sore flaws, then "The Man With the Iron Fists" was entertaining and full of fighting and action. It is well worth sitting down to watch.

movie_name: The Man with the Iron Fists
review_title: A cracking homage to the kung fu genre, from a fan for the fans.
review_detailed_main: Who doesn't love a movie where a swift roundhouse kick to the head completely dislodges said head from its body allowing gallons of blood to squirt out and drench anything in close proximity? I know I do. It's this gleeful lack of regard for realism from writer-director-composer-star RZA – a renowned martial arts enthusiast – that frees up TMWTIF to be exactly what it aims for: silly, unhinged entertainment to sate the genre fanatics. The cracking old-school opening credits sequence sets the tone early and from there RZA rarely lets the pace slip; if not presenting a well-choreographed, often ultra-violent scrap, he's allowing his eclectic cast (Russell Crowe, Lucy Liu, Byron Mann) to sprout Tarantino-esque dialogue at each other with venomous joy. Special mention to the anachronistic soundtrack too, it's a sublime blend of modern gangster hip-hop and an over-the-top 70's eastern score, giving the chop-socky action a perfect accompanying beat. It's unashamedly all style over substance, but who cares – not me! – this is a coolly-constructed, suitably frenetic homage to the kung fu genre, from a fan for the fans.

review_title: A great homage to B Kung Fu movies but RZA is no actor.
review_detailed_main:
'THE MAN WITH THE IRON FISTS': Four Stars (Out of Five)

Rap artist RZA directed, co-wrote (with horror director Eli Roth) and stars in this homage to classic B Kung Fu films. The film co-stars the likes of Russell Crowe, Lucy Liu, Rick Yune, Chung Le, Byron Mann, Dave Bautista and Jamie Chung. The story revolves around a blacksmith (played by RZA) who teams with a rogue British soldier and a Chinese warrior out for revenge to defend his village from a vicious clan of traitors. The movie is a great homage to B Kung Fu movies; it's got lots of stylish and campy fight scenes, sex and gore and should more than please most fans of the genre.

The film is set in 19th century China in the town of Jungle Village. RZA plays a freed slave turned loner blacksmith who is called on to make deadly weapons for most of the townsfolk. Crowe plays a British soldier named Jack Knife, who's named after his special weapon, and is visiting the town's brothel ran by Madam Blossom (Liu). When the Lion Clan, lead by Silver Lion (Mann) and Bronze Lion (Le), kill their former leader and threaten the village the Blacksmith teams with Jack Knife and a lone warrior out to avenge his father's death, known as The X-Blade (Yune), to defend the townsfolk. Chaos and violence ensues.

Quentin Tarantino lent his name to the film (in a 'presented by' credit) but served no other purpose in the production. RZA did learn a lot by watching him on the set of 'KILL BILL' though (while he was doing the soundtrack for that film) and it shows. The film is produced in a style most would call Tarantino-esque and RZA does show a lot of talent as an action film director. He and Roth's script is decent as well but RZA is no actor. He says little in the film but his presence as the lead still brings the film's quality down a bit. The rest of the cast is more than adequate though and they do help make up for RZA's poor performance. Like I said there's plenty of great martial arts action, gore and sex to please any hardcore genre fan and the women are very beautiful to look at as well (I've been a big fan of Liu's for a while). It's a fun B Kung Fu movie that serves it's purpose well.

movie_name: The Man with the Iron Fists
review_detailed_main:
I Normally consider my self a movie buff or at least I used to, until this last year I used to go to the Cinema 2 times a week.

Sadly this year while having some really Amazing box office smashes such as "The Avengers" and "The Dark Knight Rises" and a few other note worthy flick's like "The Hunger Games" or "Prometheus" I have for the most not really felt the need to go out and watch much of anything. While I can named at lest 100+ movies I saw in 2011/2010 off the top of my head. So far this year I have gone out to see. John Carter, Battleship, Safe house, Prometheus, The Hunger Games, The Expendables, The Avengers, The Dark Knight Rises

Oh yeah the 3D Titanic- Wife Agroo.

So while not seeing much in the way of movies this year. It seems likes it takes a lot just to get up and go see any movie adventure this year or maybe we have been spoiled by the 2 big movies. Who knows. The Man With the Iron Fists

The movie starts off like all Martial Arts movies do intruding all the main players however you not sure who the bad guy is until it visually shown on screen which in turn gives us the setting or the idea where we don't know who the bad guys or who the good guys are as we meet them. The first half of the movie is narrated by the Blacksmith/THE RZA at which point he becomes the main character of the film. a few character feel out of place like the X-Blade/Rick Yune where hes only played a bad guys in films so you assume the same here. Jack knife/Russell Crowe is the comic relief but with attitude. he basically get all the good lines and steels the show. Madam Blossom/Lucy Liu is the brothel Madam whose brothel is where the whole movie takes place. Lucy Liu give one of her better performances in this movie and I say this because She is the only movie character I have seen in a long time where I not sure if I am supposed to love her or hate her. Every fight seen the movie is well choreographed and equally as brutal, The Directer takes a few liberties with cinematography which most cases work well. There are a few spots mostly when dealing with Brass Body where the CGI is just horrible but the parts are few and I give it up to being a low budget movie and The RZA first time in Directors seat. The movie has many sexually references but no nudity and mostly uses this as humor which works well in the film. Despite it taking place in a brothel there only one scene which may depict women in a derogatory way but this has meaning and is revealed a short time later in the film while also making me unsure of where or not to love or hate Lucy Liu in the movie.

My only issue in the movie is the final fight scenes at no point did it seem like the good guys were gonna lose. The Bruce lee homage with the room of mirrors what cut 99% away to save time in the movie and/or make room for the other 2 final fight scene.

All in all the movie is amazing and I give it a 85/100 The movie lost 10 points for the Bruce Lee "Enter the Dragon" room of mirrors abomination.
